Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Particle Physics Research at SUNY Albany
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for a group with one PI, a postdoc and a student to work on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC is a large, complex machine that accelerates protons to unprecedented energies, allowing for discovery of elementary particles more massive than any yet observed. One of the LHC's recent discoveries was to find a candidate for the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts with amazing accuracy for the observed interactions of particles forming the visible matter in the universe. The next step is to capitalize on the LHC to look for evidence for physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) to address difficulties known to exist in the SM. This group will continue to work on the ATLAS experiment to look for decays of the Higgs particle as the LHC begins operations at twice the energy ever studied before. The PI will continue to communicate the excitement that the Higgs discovery generated as a means of attracting students into the study of science through such activities as giving lectures on Physics at the LHC to high school students in Albany and the Honors College students at the university, organizing and holding Q&A sessions after the screening of the movie "Particle Fever" in local area theaters, and participating in the online "Adopt-a-Physicist" program run by the American Physical Society.

The LHC has completed one successful run. During this, a candidate for the Higgs Boson was found, a major triumph. Though doubts linger, many physicists believe the new particle is the Higgs Boson long predicted by the SM. Nevertheless, more careful measurements of its rarer decay modes need to be made. Surprises are possible, and could result from BSM effects. Also, there could be more than one Higgs particle. This group has expertise in analysis of the properties of Higgs decays. The group will continue to work on the ATLAS experiment through Run2. Analyses will focus on decays of the Higgs particle revealed in Run1 to t-tbar quark jet pairs. The group will continue to improve and expand the software tools. They will also study layout designs for the inner Silicon tracker, part of the ATLAS high luminosity upgrade. These layouts will aim to maximize the efficiency for finding and reconstructing charged tracks in the challenging ATLAS upgrade environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of Particle Physics aims to study the fundamental building blocks of matter and the forces with which they interact with each other. Over the last 75 years, this field has made tremendous progress and we have a spectacularly successful theory known as the Standard Model (SM). However, the SM is incomplete, and projects like the one described here are expected to help complete the picture.

This project used data generated by colliding two high-energy proton beams, produced by the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Switzerland, at the center of the ATLAS detector. Members of the Principal Investigator's (PI) group also worked on an upgrade of the ATLAS detector. The upgraded detector is scheduled to start operating in 2026, and is expected to collect about 20 times the current data set; this will lead to an unprecedented test of the SM, and potentially make discoveries beyond the SM.

The Higgs boson is the keystone of the SM - among other things, it gives mass to all known fundamental particles like quarks and leptons (which are electron-like particles). One of the aims of this project was to study the production of the Higgs boson in association with top-quark pairs, which measures the interaction strength of the Higgs boson and top quarks. Since the top quark is very heavy (weighing as much as a gold atom), this interaction is very special within the SM. Our results combined with other channels led to the observation of this rare process in 2018. This re-confirmed the validity of the SM.

We also investigated other processes, allowed in the SM, that mimic various aspects of Higgs boson production and decay. An understanding of such processes (aka backgrounds) is crucial to discovering physics beyond the SM. One background we studied was the production of a pair of bottom-quarks in association with top-quarks; this background looks very much like the above-mentioned process where the Higgs boson (decaying into a pair of bottom-quarks) is produced in association with a pair of top-quarks. The first result was published in 2019. Another topic we studied was the production of a pair of bottom-quarks in association with a Z boson (one of the carriers of the weak force); this process forms a background to the production of a Higgs boson (decaying to pair of bottom-quarks) in association with a Z boson. The result is being readied for publication.

In order to keep up with developments in technology and accelerator performance, the ATLAS detector is continually upgraded. Detectors in our field are technologically very sophisticated and make extremely precise measurements; for instance, the tracking sub-system, which measures the trajectory of charged particles (e.g., electrons, protons) as they traverse the detector, has components that can resolve electronic signals separated in space by about 10 microns (i.e., 1/10 the thickness of human hair). We worked on the upgrade that is scheduled to come on-line in 2026; in particular we contributed to the design of the tracking sub-system.

In the future, the proton beams delivered by the LHC will be very intense and each resulting collision is expected to produce about 2000 charged particles, which need to have their trajectories accurately and precisely measured; these collisions occur 40 million times/second. Both requirements pose enormous challenges for the design of the tracking sub-system. The layout of this sub-system is close to being finalized; details can be found in two technical design reports. Construction will begin soon.

To propagate and share the excitement of this field to the community at large, the PI gives informal lectures at various venues in and around Albany, e.g. the PI started a lecture series at the local public library on particle physics and related sub-fields like astrophysics. The talks (usually six lectures per year) are aimed at the general public, and are free of charge.

In addition, the PI and his colleagues at the University at Albany twice organized a 2-day mini-school on particle physics aimed at local area high school students. This was done in collaboration with the local Museum of Science and Innovation. The reviews were very positive and we plan to make this an annual event.

Lastly, the PI's research group includes both graduate and under-graduate students. The training they receive gives them specialized skills that are outside those learned in a classroom setting. In addition, it readies the next generation of particle physicists.
